I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  The Government of the People’s Republic of China (PRC) has requested that the Asian 
Development Bank (ADB) provide technical assistance (TA) for managing railway passenger 
operations more efficiently. The Fact-Finding Mission visited the PRC in September 2006 and 
reached an understanding with the Government on TA objectives, scope, terms of reference, 
cost estimates, financing plan, and implementation arrangements. The TA is included in the 
ADB 2006 country program for the PRC.1 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
2.  Economic growth in the PRC has been rapid over the past 2 decades, reaching 10.2% in 
2005. The rapid economic growth has resulted in 9% annual growth in passenger transport and 
7.4% growth in freight transport from 1978 to 2005. During that period, railway freight grew from 
535 billion tons/kilometer (km) to 2,073 billion tons/km, for an annual growth rate of 5.1%, and 
passenger traffic grew at 6.6% annually, increasing from 109 billion passenger-km to 606 billion 
passenger-km. Despite this growth in traffic, railways lost modal share for both freight and 
passengers. By end 2005, the PRC’s railway system comprised 75,438 route-km, which carried 
about a third of the PRC’s freight and passenger traffic.  
 
3.  The Government’s railway development policy focuses on (i) removing constraints and 
expanding the railway system, (ii) encouraging the construction of joint venture local railways to 
promote the development of local economies, (iii) improving the railway system’s efficiency by 
using new technology and modern management tools for planning and operations, (iv) reducing 
operating subsidies through appropriate pricing and commercialization of services, (v) initiating 
institutional  and  structural  reforms  to  increase  Ministry  of  Railways  (MOR)  autonomy  and 
accountability, and (vi) encouraging nongovernment investment in infrastructure and related 
services.  
 
4.  The Tenth Five-Year Plan (2001–2005) identified railway development as a priority and 
envisaged (i) building 6,000 km of new lines to access previously unserved areas, bringing the 
network length to 74,000 km; (ii) providing 3,000 km of double lines and electrifying 5,000 km of 
key lines to increase capacity; and (iii) increasing operating speeds on 5,000 km to reach a total 
length of speed-improved lines of 15,000 km. An investment of CNY270 billion was envisaged 
for capital construction. By the end of 2005, an investment of CNY308 billion had been made for 
capital construction, which included (i) constructing 6,458 km of new lines, (ii) providing 3,275 
km of double lines, and (iii) electrifying 6,259 km of tracks.  
 
5.  In 2004, the State Council approved the new Railway Development Plan covering the 
period up to 2020. The plan seeks to expand the railway network from 74,000 km in 2004 to 
100,000 km by 2020. Increasing train speed is identified as a major goal. Train speeds will be 
raised to over 200 km per hour on the trunk network by 2020. Priority will be given to developing 
railways in unserved areas and regions that lack transport and have remained less developed. 
The route network length will increase by 16,000 km in the western region of the PRC to reach a 
network length of 40,000 km by 2020. To improve operational efficiency, MOR has initiated 
action to separate passenger and freight trains on key rail corridors.2

6.  The  Eleventh  Five-Year  Plan  (2006–2010)  continues  the  emphasis  on  railway 
development  and  seeks  to  accelerate  railway  construction.  The  plan,  which  is  under 
preparation,  envisages  (i) constructing  17,000  km  of  new  lines  so  that  the  network  length 
reaches a total of 92,000 route-km and (ii) double tracking and electrifying 45% of the network 
length.  The  plan seeks  to  (i) build  a  dedicated  passenger  railway  network  by  constructing 
passenger-dedicated  lines  (PDLs);  (ii)  develop  coal  transport  corridors  by  increasing  the 
capacity of the existing lines; (iii) expand the railway network in the poor western region to 
34,000 km; (iv) build international corridors at the borders in the southwest and northwest; and 
(v)  develop  a  countrywide  intermodal  container  network.  Preliminary  estimates  suggest 
investments of CNY1.5 trillion, or about $190 billion over the next 5-year period.  
 
7.  ADB's strategy for the PRC railway sector focuses on (i) expanding the railway system 
by constructing new lines in unserved areas that are less-developed and poor; (ii) modernizing 
and increasing the capacity to improve transport efficiency on key routes of the national railway 
system;  (iii)  commercializing  railway  operations  to  sustain  efficient  operations,  and 
(iv) increasing railway competitiveness in the transport sector through restructuring and reform.  
 
8.  ADB  is  the  lead  funding  agency  in  the  PRC  railway  sector  and  has  focused  on 
developing railways in less-developed inland provinces to promote growth and reduce poverty. 
ADB provided 13 loans, totaling about $2.6 billion, to finance the construction of about 1,921 km 
of provincial railways and 4,597 km of national railway projects. The World Bank has since 1984 
provided 10 loans totaling over $2.4 billion for (i) nine national railway projects to expand railway 
capacity  on  high-priority  corridors,  modernizing  technology,  and  strengthening  institutional 
capabilities and (ii) one local railway project. From 1979 to 1997, Japan provided about Y558 
billion for 15 railway projects to expand rail transportation capacity.   
 
9.  Policy dialogue has been a significant component of ADB assistance to the railway 
sector and has effectively complemented lending operations. A total of 12 TA projects have 
been  provided  to  PRC  railways  since  1989  for  (i)  policy  reforms,  (ii)  the  institutional 
development  of  local  railways,  (iii)  strengthening  commercial  and  business  operations,  (iv) 
marketing  and  business  development,  (v)  tariff  setting  with  improved  cost  recovery,  (vi) 
developing human resources, and (vii) improving the financial management and accounting 
systems.  Since  2002,  ADB  has  enhanced  its  policy  dialogue  with  MOR,  the  National 
Development Reform Commission (NDRC), and the Ministry of Finance (MOF), and there is 
broad agreement that reform is an engine to further develop railways. The World Bank and the 
Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) have also been engaged in 
dialogues on many policy issues concerning PRC railways. The Railway Development Plan 
(2004) sets major goals and the reform agenda up to 2020 for PRC railway development. This 
plan seeks to (i) study and learn from worldwide experience, (ii) clearly identify core operations 
and separate core from non-core transportation businesses, (iii) rationalize and reduce staff, (iv) 
reform the railway investment and financing system, and (v) establish specialized transportation 
companies. 
 
10.  Even though in the recent years PRC railways have made significant progress and 
notable  achievements,  they  are  unable  to  meet  increasing  demand  for  passenger 
transportation.  Growth  in  passenger  transportation  has  been  faster  than  growth  in  freight 
transport (para. 2.). High economic growth rates and increasing urbanization are the two major 
causes for this high passenger transport demand. With per capita GDP expected to grow at 7% 
and reach $3,000 by 2020, from the current level of $1,700, and with 60% of the rural population 
(400 million) expected to move to urban areas in the same period, demand for increased 
transportation capacity and quality of service will increase significantly. Even with 6.6% growth 
in the period 1978–2005, the railways’ share of total passenger transport has gone down, as 
road and air passenger transport has witnessed higher growth rates. Improved road and air

3 
networks following huge investments in the two subsectors in recent years help explain these 
high growth rates. However, PRC railways are more fuel efficient and environmentally friendly 
than road and air transport. They have an enviable safety record and are more affordable. Rail 
is  a  preferred  mode  of  transport  for  long-distance  travel,  but  there  are  serious  capacity 
constraints.  
 
11.  Given  all  of  this,  the  Government  has  adopted  an  aggressive  plan  for  developing 
railways, including the development of a dedicated passenger network, in the Eleventh Five 
Year  Plan.  MOR  has  developed  an  ambitious  plan  to  develop  12,000  km  of  dedicated 
passenger railway network by 2020. ADB has supported the concept of a dedicated passenger 
network in the PRC railway system and is financing the Zhengzhou-Xi’an PDL, the construction 
of which started in September 2005. MOR has started building another 10 PDLs, and 5,000 km 
of the dedicated passenger network will be completed by the end of the Eleventh Five Year Plan 
(2010).  
 
12.  Developing a dedicated passenger network is a new concept for PRC railways, and 
managing such a network is different from managing a conventional railway system that runs 
both freight and passenger services on the same tracks. MOR has no experience in operating 
and managing such a network and is therefore looking for international experience and best 
practices to support managing it efficiently. A number of key issues need to be considered. One 
is train operation planning for dedicated corridors, which is different from the train operation 
planning  for  mixed  traffic  lines  and  corridors;  safety,  reliability,  and  punctuality  are  key 
parameters to decide the number of trains that can run between destinations and how they can 
run. The method, basis, process, and models for planning train operations on a network and 
origin-destination basis, as well as planning of train links, traffic flows, train servicing, link plans, 
and other operating parameters for PDLs, are different from those of conventional railway lines. 
A related safety issue is the need for a decision-support system for the day-to-day management 
of  operations.  The  contents,  organization  methods,  implementation  methods,  processes  of 
related  works,  management  regulations,  setting  up  and  functioning  of  the  framework,  and 
customer relations management methods for conventional train operations are much different 
from those of dedicated operations. As MOR has no experience in these areas, it is seeking to 
learn from similar experiences in other countries.  
 
13.  Another issue is the viability of the dedicated passenger operations. MOR has adopted a 
separate  institutional  structure  for  these  entities,  and  each  PDL  has  been  formed  into  a 
separate, legally independent, financially viable joint venture entity.3 This approach is quite 
different from the approach adopted by MOR for the national network, where cross-subsidies 
and distortions exist in pricing, and where tariffs are set by the Government. To make these 
entities commercially viable, pricing policies and tariff strategies need to be adopted that are 
very different from those of the conventional network. Concepts such as full cost recovery, 
flexible pricing mechanisms, basing tariffs on market conditions, and different tariff structures for 
different quality of services are some of the options that need to be examined. PDLs will cater to 
different sections of society and compete with conventional railways, airways, and roads. Given 
the intense competition that is likely to emerge from other transportation modes, an effective 
sales and marketing strategy will determine where the traffic goes. Again, marketing is not an 
area of strength for conventional railways, where most of the traffic is captive and bulk, requiring 
very  little  marketing  or  sales  effort  from  the  railways.  MOR  therefore  seeks  to  research 
international experiences, learn from them, and suitably adopt best practices over its system. A 
related issue for the efficient operation of passenger services is the efficacy of such supporting 
transport services as on-board train services, passenger amenities, station facilities, information

systems, reservation systems, etc. For conventional train operations, these services are not  
very important, but in the case of dedicated premium services they can determine customer 
choice and passenger flows. 
 
14.  Addressing these issues is critical to achieving safe, reliable, and commercially viable 
dedicated passenger operations on PRC railways. Given ADB’s role in developing the concept 
of a dedicated passenger network, and that the commercial operation of the first PDL (Beijing–
Tianjin) is expected to start in 2008, the Government and MOR sought ADB assistance to help 
PRC railways research international experiences and best practices for these new concepts, 
examine how they can be adopted to PRC railways, and make recommendations for MOR to 
implement.   
 
II.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
15.  The impact of the proposed TA is an efficient, reliable, and competitive passenger 
railway transport system developed in the PRC. The outcome of TA will be a strategy that can 
be adopted by MOR to manage railway passenger operations more efficiently. TA will (i) review 
current  practices  adopted  by  MOR  for  managing  passenger  operations,  (ii) research  best 
international practices and experiences, and (iii) recommend actions that should be realistic for 
the  Government  and  MOR  to  implement.  Appendix  1  gives  the  design  and  monitoring 
framework. The study will use the experience of other railways and involve active participation 
of railway management. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
 
16.  International consultants, supported by national consultants, will be engaged to help the 
Government  prepare  the  recommendations  and  a  plan  that  MOR  can  implement.  The 
consultants will  
(i)  review development plans of the dedicated passenger network and PDLs and 
prepare guidelines for the plan for passenger operations;  
(ii)  reviewsales and marketing strategies adopted by similar railways and prepare a 
strategy to be adopted by MOR for PDLs;  
(iii)  review  pricing  and  tariff  policies  for  passenger  operations,  research  similar 
international experience, and recommend  appropriate pricing policies and tariff 
structures that can be adopted by MOR; 
(iv)  research international experiences in developing such support services as on-
board  train  services,  station  services,  the  provision  of  passenger  amenities, 
ticketing, and passenger information systems on similar railways, recommending 
an appropriate system that can be adopted by MOR; and  
(v)  research and review decision-support systems for the day-to-day management 
decisions  made  while  operating  dedicated  passenger  railway  operations, 
recommending suitable decision-support systems that can be adopted by MOR. 
 
17.  TA will be undertaken in close consultation with the Government, MOR, and other 
relevant agencies. The study will build upon ADB’s ongoing policy dialogue and the outputs of 
recent  TA  provided  for  policy  reform  support.4  It  will  consider  all  previous  studies  by  the 
Government, ADB, World Bank, OECD, other multilateral agencies, and bilateral agencies. TA 
                                                 
4 ADB. 2005. Technical Assistance to the People’s Republic of China for the Railway Passenger and Freight Policy 
Reform Study. Manila. The study is ongoing.

5 
will involve analytical and innovative research; fieldwork; training; and stakeholder consultations 
with the Government, private sector, user groups, and international development partners. 
 
18.  Key activities will include a review of existing studies by MOR, the Government, and 
other multilateral institutions; data analysis; and consultation with other stakeholders, including 
MOF and government officials. An international training program with participation from relevant 
departments  will  be  organized  to  learn  from  the  experiences  of  railways  overseas.  Two 
workshops, one each at inception and the interim stage of TA implementation, will be organized 
to discuss and review the findings of the study, and a seminar will be organized at the final 
stage to disseminate TA findings.  
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
19.  The total cost of TA is estimated at $780,000. TA will be financed as a grant in the 
amount of $600,000 from ADB’s TA funding program. MOR will finance the remaining $180,000, 
which  will  be  used  to  cover  office  accommodation  and  the  counterpart  staff  required  to 
implement TA. The detailed cost estimate is in Appendix 2.    
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
20.  MOR, as the Executing Agency, will be responsible for supervising and monitoring TA 
activities. A steering committee comprising representatives of relevant departments of MOR will 
be set up to oversee implementation and provide guidance and direction to the consultants. In 
addition, MOR will appoint a project coordinator who will supervise and coordinate day-to-day 
TA  activities,  including  monitoring  progress,  resolving  problems,  arranging  meetings,  and 
liaising with the government agencies concerned. To facilitate the work of the consultants, and 
to ensure that MOR benefits from their experience, MOR will provide adequate counterpart staff 
with relevant work experience during TA implementation. MOR will also provide policy guidance 
to the consultants. Workshops and a seminar will be held to review findings at the inception, 
interim, and final stages of TA. These meetings will include representatives of MOR, MOF, other 
relevant agencies, ADB, and the consultants. A final report will be published at TA completion. 
 
21.  A consulting firm will be engaged by ADB using simplified technical proposal procedures 
and the quality- and cost-based selection method in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the 
Use of Consultants (2005) and other arrangements satisfactory to ADB for engaging national 
consultants. TA will require about 18 person-months of international consulting services and 
about 20 person-months of national consulting services to carry out the terms of reference 
(Appendix 3). The international consultants will have expertise in the following fields of the railway 
passenger transport: (i) railway transportation planning, (ii) sales and marketing, (iii) pricing policy 
and tariff issues, (iv) related transport services for railways, and (v) railway management decision-
support systems. The national consultants will have expertise in the following fields of railway 
passenger transport: (i) train operation planning, (ii) sales and marketing strategies, (iii) pricing 
and tariff issues, (iv) transport services, and (v) decision-support systems for managing railways. 
TA  is  expected  to  commence  in  February  2007  and  be  completed  by  September  2007. 
Procurement of equipment, supplies, and materials by consultants under TA will follow ADB’s 
Procurement Guidelines (2006). The equipment will be turned over to MOR after TA completion. 
 
III.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
22.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $600,000 on a grant basis to 
the Government of the People’s Republic of China for Managing Railway Passenger Operations 
More Efficiently, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  Scope of Services  
 
1.  The proposed technical assistance (TA) to the People’s Republic of China (PRC) for 
Managing Railway Passenger Operations More Efficiently will help the Government and the 
Ministry of Railways (MOR) prepare a strategy to manage passenger railway operations more 
efficiently. TA will (i) review the current practices adopted by MOR for managing passenger 
operations,  (ii)  research  best  international  practices  and  experiences,  and  (iii)  recommend 
actions that should be realistic for the Government and MOR to implement. The study will 
research international experience for developing passenger railway operations, adopt the best 
practices to local conditions, and help prepare a strategy to manage passenger operations more 
efficiently.  
 
B.  Terms of Reference 
 
2.  The tasks under TA will include, but not necessarily be limited to, the following: 
 
3.  Train Operation Planning Specialist. (4 person-months each for international and 
national). The consultants will undertake a comprehensive review of the development of the 
dedicated  passenger  railway  network  and  passenger-dedicated  lines  (PDLs)  in  the  PRC, 
research similar railways, and prepare guidelines on transportation plans on origin–destination, 
and network basis. The guidelines will include suggestions on how to adjust train operations 
under varying situations regarding traffic and technical requirements. Guidelines explaining the 
method, basis, process, and models for planning train operations—taking into account issues 
like  link  planning,  line  capacity,  train  planning,  train  servicing,  seasonal  traffic  flows, 
locomotive/electrical  motor  unit  link  plans,  and  other  operating  parameters—will  be 
recommended.  
 
4.  Sales and Marketing Specialist. (3 person-months international and 4 person-months 
national)  The  consultants  will  examine  the  existing  system  of  marketing  for  PRC  railway 
passenger transport, and research the methods, basis, processes, and models adopted by 
similar railways, towards preparing the sales and marketing strategy. Based on this research, 
recommend an appropriate sales and marketing strategy that can be adopted by MOR for 
PDLs. This should include recommendations for the appropriate method, basis, process, and 
model to be adopted by MOR for decisions, adjustment, implementation, and evaluation of the 
marketing strategy, including analyses and forecasts of the market, sales strategy, promotion 
strategy, and customer relations management. Innovative methods or steps adopted by similar 
railways should be included in the recommendations. Given the constraints of supply and 
demand and the limits on forecasting, recommend, based on international experience, special 
products or services and innovative approaches on product pricing and service quality that MOR 
can adopt. 
 
5.  Pricing and Tariff Specialist. (4 person-months each for international and national) The 
consultants will undertake a critical review of pricing policies and tariff structures for passenger 
operations on PRC railways. Research similar international experience for dedicated passenger 
operations and put forward a method, basis, process, and model that can be adopted by MOR 
for decision-making, adjustment, implementation, and evaluation of the pricing policy and the 
tariff strategy for PDLs. Examine how to introduce transport-pricing reforms in which the market 
is the key factor and national guidelines have only minor influence. Suggest a flexible pricing 
mechanism  in  which  prices  can  change  according  to  market  conditions.  Recommend  an 
appropriate pricing policy and tariff structure that can be adopted by MOR for its system.  
 
6.  Transport  Services  Specialist.  (3  person-months  for  international  and  4  person-
months for national) The consultants will research international experiences in developing such

10   
railway transport support services such as the process of works, on-board train services, station 
services, provision of passenger amenities, ticketing, and passenger information systems on 
similar passenger railways. Evaluate how these experiences can be adopted by MOR and 
recommend an appropriate system that can be adopted by MOR. Examine the prospects for 
private sector involvement in managing and operating these services. Study the mechanism for 
guaranteeing service quality in passenger railway transportation, including management content 
and standards and who and how to manage it. Recommend a fair and objective evaluation 
system  for  monitoring  the  service  quality  of  passenger  railway  transportation,  including 
standards and who and how to make the evaluation.   
 
7.  Railway Management Decision-Support System Specialist. (4 person-months each 
for international and national) The consultants will undertake comprehensive research and 
review of the decision-support system for the day-to-day management decisions for operating 
passenger  railway  operations  on  PRC  railways  and  similar  passenger  railways  in  other 
countries. Evaluate the systems’ content, organization, and implementation methods; processes 
of related works; management regulations; setting up and functioning of the framework; and 
customer relations-management to identify methods that can be adopted for PDLs. Based on 
this review and evaluation, recommend a suitable decision-support system to be adopted by 
MOR.   
 
8.  Based  on  international  experiences  and  best  practices,  the  consultants  will  study 
computerization  for  passenger  transportation,  examining  (i)  its  aspects  regarding  services, 
management, and decision-making; (ii) how to realize information computerization, including 
sources and utilization of funds, information transmission among different departments, and 
information  merging  among  different  systems;  and  (iii)  the  development  of  e-commerce, 
including the scope of business, development means, and fundraising. Examine the potential for 
private sector involvement in developing, managing, and operating these facilities.   
 
9.  The consultants will review and build on the previous studies and reports prepared by 
the Asian Development Bank (ADB),1 World Bank, MOR, and/or other development partners. 
They will review lessons learned from the experience of other countries in developing similar 
passenger  railway  operations.  As  part  of  this  exercise,  they  will  prepare  and  implement 
overseas training for government officials of the relevant departments. This will be undertaken 
after the submission of the interim report. The contents of the training program and list of 
participants will require ADB approval. 
 
10.  The consultants will organize two workshops at the inception and interim report stage 
and one seminar at the draft final report stage to discuss the findings and disseminate the 
outcome of the TA. 
C.  Reporting Requirements 
 
11.  The consultants will submit the following reports: (i) an inception report 3 weeks after 
commencement of services, (ii) an interim report after 12 weeks, (iii) a draft final report after 22 
weeks, and (iv) a final report, including key findings and recommendations (5 pages), after 7 
months. MOR requires five copies of each report in English and Chinese, and the Ministry of 
Finance (TA Division) needs two copies of each report in English and Chinese. ADB requires 
five copies of each report in English. The final report will be edited for bilingual publication. All 
reports will be submitted both in hard copy and electronically.
